poem:
Hypnosis at the Bakery

Before laughter turned bread into air,
a mother at Tesco  
spun dough into Mediterranean nights,
her children's lunches a canvas—
focaccia, olives, whispers of thyme—
defying the shelves,
the checkouts, the aisles full of simple bread.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Comedian Fern Brady: ‘I went to get hypnotised out of eating bread’ Mum was really into getting me and my brothers to try different foods. Which is why I resent any depictions of working-class people just eating Turkey Twizzlers because my mum used to bake us focaccia and stuff. She worked in Tesco on the checkout but she’d have Greek food nights for us. We were always the children with weird packed lunches. I’ve never". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
